references: Wright, P. L., and C. H. Conaway. 1950. White-tailed Ptarmigan in the Mission Mountains, Montana. Condor 52:238.

Hoffman, R.W. 2006. White-tailed Ptarmigan (Lagopus leucura): a technical conservation assessment. [Online]. USDA Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Region. Available: http://www.fs.fed.us/r2/projects/scp/assessments/whitetailedptarmigan.pdf

Clarke, J. A., and R. E. Johnson. 1992. The influence of spring snow depth on White-tailed Ptarmigan breeding success in the Sierra Nevada. Condor 94:622-627.
Braun, C.E., R.W. Hoffman, and G.E. Rogers. 1976. Wintering areas and winter ecology of white-tailed ptarmigan in Colorado. Special Report 38. Colorado Division of Wildlife, Fort Collins, CO, USA.

Zeiner, D. C., W. F. Laudenslayer Jr., and K. E. Mayer (editors). 1990. California's Wildlife. Vol. 2. Birds. California Statewide Wildlife Habitat Relat. System, California. Resources Agency, Dept. Fish and Game, Sacramento, California.

Herzog, P.W. 1980. Winter habitat use by white-tailed ptarmigan in southwestern Alberta. Canadian Field-Naturalist 94:159-162.
habitat_description:
Lagopus leucura inhabits alpine environments with abundant rock cover, dwarf willow, and ample snow cover (Choate, 1963; Herzog, 1977; Giesen et al., 1980; Herzog, 1980; Zeiner et al., 1990; Frederick and Gutierrez, 1992; Giesen and Braun, 1992; Hoffman, 2006). The species avoids areas of tall vegetation (>30 cm) (Choate, 1963; Herzog, 1977), but can sometimes be found in subalpine meadows or other openings below treeline (Braun et al., 1976; Herzog, 1980).

Typically found just above treeline, the white-tailed ptarmigan has been documented at elevations as low as 1950 m in Montana, to as high as 4420 m (SW ReGAP).
